title: Camshaft - Installation

body.body: Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall, causing injury to the operator or damage to the motorcycle.
Accurate camshaft timing can only be obtained using the correct timing method and service tools as described below.
The camshaft sprockets are attached to the camshafts using slotted fixing holes. This allows for very accurate valve timing and therefore improved performance and fuel economy.

Never fit the camshaft sprockets without correctly setting the camshaft timing using the service tools and timing procedure described below. Severe engine damage will result from incorrect valve timing adjustment.
If not already installed, install the
Thoroughly clean the camshaft and journals. Lubricate the camshaft with clean engine oil before fitting to the cylinder head.
Ensure the sprocket fixings are centrally located within the slotted holes of the sprocket.
DO NOT tighten the fixings at this stage; the sprocket must be free to rotate.
If removed, refit the camshaft sprocket noting its orientation, and secure using the original fixings.
Locate the camshaft to the cylinder head from the right hand side, hooking the camshaft drive chain over the sprocket.
Align the slot in the camshaft end to the upper surface of the cylinder head.
Lift the camshaft slightly from the bearing journals, refit the camshaft drive chain tensioner blade. Tighten the new fixings to
It is not necessary to fit the rocker arms at this stage.
Temporarily secure number two cylinder camshaft ladder to the cylinder head with a rocker shaft and one fixing,
Adjust the camshaft sprocket, so that the camshaft chain is taut on the inlet side (rear) of the engine.
Ensure there is no slack in the chain between the crankshaft and the sprocket and the sprocket fixings are centrally located within the slotted holes.

To activate the tensioner, rotate the crankshaft anti-clockwise two complete turns, using the fixing fitted to the end of the crankshaft. Stop rotation when number 1 cylinder is at top dead centre (TDC).
Before inserting the timing pin, ensure the slot on the camshaft is aligned with the upper surface of the cylinder head.

Lubricate the camshaft bearing areas of the camshaft frame with a 50/50 solution of engine oil and molybdenum disulphide grease.
Fit the shims to the valves as noted during removal.
Position cylinder one camshaft frame to the cylinder head.
Lubricate the threads of the camshaft frame fixings with clean engine oil.
Fit the rocker shafts with the dot marks facing upwards and toward the camshaft drive gear.
Fit the inlet and exhaust rocker shafts, and cam frame supports as noted during removal, to cylinder number one as shown below. Do not fully tighten at this stage.
Finger-tighten the fixings until the under head areas are in contact with the camshaft frame.
Remove the fixing and rocker shaft from cylinder number two camshaft frame.
Lubricate the threads of the camshaft frame fixings with clean engine oil.
The rocker shaft must be fitted with the dot marks facing upwards and toward the camshaft drive gear.
Fit the inlet and exhaust rockers and shafts to cylinder number two. Do not fully tighten at this stage.
Finger tighten the fixings until the rocker shafts are in contact with the camshaft frame.

To avoid damage to the camshaft frame, always ensure as many camshaft lobes as possible are facing away from the rocker shaft. This will reduce stress on the camshaft frame during assembly. Damage to the camshaft frame will result in replacement of the cylinder head.
Tighten cylinder one camshaft frame fixings, until the camshaft frames are in full contact with the cylinder head. Tighten the fixings in the sequence shown below to
Cylinder One Camshaft Frame Tightening Sequence
Tighten cylinder two camshaft frame fixings, until the camshaft frames are in full contact with the cylinder head. Tighten the fixings in the sequence shown below to
Cylinder Two Camshaft Frame Tightening Sequence
Tighten cylinder one camshaft frame fixings in the sequence shown below to
Cylinder One Camshaft Frame Tightening Sequence
Tighten cylinder two camshaft frame fixings in the sequence shown below to
Cylinder Two Camshaft Frame Tightening Sequence

If any components have been renewed, the valve clearances must be checked and adjusted. Running with incorrectly adjusted valve clearances may cause excess engine noise, rough running and engine damage.
